content.text: Pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) is a contagious bacterial infection that primarily affects the lungs but can spread to other parts of the body. It is caused by the bacterium Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

items: Persistent cough lasting more than 3 weeks, often with sputum production (may be bloody)

appliesTo.description: All patients with new-onset pulmonary TB

regimenData.notes: Standard four-drug regimen (RIPE). Ethambutol can be discontinued if drug susceptibility testing shows sensitivity to isoniazid and rifampin.
The continuation phase is extended to 7 months (for a total of 9 months of therapy) in patients with cavitary pulmonary disease whose sputum culture at 2 months is positive.

diagnosticTestData.name: Sputum Smear and Culture
diagnosticTestData.notes: At least 3 sputum specimens should be collected for acid-fast bacilli (AFB) smear and mycobacterial culture. Culture is the gold standard.

diagnosticTestData.name: Nucleic Acid Amplification Test (NAAT)
diagnosticTestData.notes: Recommended for at least one sputum specimen. Provides rapid identification of M. tuberculosis.

diagnosticTestData.name: Chest X-ray
diagnosticTestData.interpretation: Typical findings include upper lobe infiltrates, cavitation, and hilar adenopathy. However, findings can be variable.
